content.title: Hotel Indigo Tchaikovskogo tells the story of the city

introduction.small: Saint Petersburg's major monuments and main street are only a stone's throw. The Hotel Indigo Tchaikovskogo is therefore a choice location to explore the city on foot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Indigo Tchaikovskogo tells the story of the city

paragraphs.text:
For its first Russian establishment, the Indigo group chose to set up base in the heart of Saint Petersburg's historical centre. It is located only ten minutes from Nevsky Prospect, the city's main street, and remains close to all the monuments that tell the construction of what is considered Russia's cultural hub. The famous past history of the town built by Peter the Great is felt in every corner of this four-star establishment: for instance, on the frescoes that adorn every neoclassical room. As for the suites, their decoration draws inspiration from Russian composer Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky, who spent most of his life in Saint Petersburg and subsequently gave his name to this address. Climb up to the rooftop terrace and take in the riveting panorama offered by the former imperial capital, as well as the Neva flowing down. The city's other symbol, its riverbanks, are a mere bike ride away. In that regard, the hotel lends guests some bicycles, free of charge, for families to enjoy a stroll. Are you ready to explore the city's past history?

Hotel Indigo St. Petersburg - Tchaikovskogo

content.title: Kvartira Kosti Kreutz, when an apartment hides a restaurant

introduction.small: Perched on the last floor of a Saint Petersburg apartment building, Kvartira Kosti Kreutz is unusual in more than one way: apartment, restaurant, tea salon and art gallery all at once.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kvartira Kosti Kreutz, when an apartment hides a restaurant

paragraphs.text:
There is something delightfully posh about the entrance of this hidden spot, located in the very heart of Saint Petersburg, close to the Nevsky Prospect. To be part of the happy few admitted inside Kvartira Kosti Kreutz (“Kreutz's apartment” in English), you literally need a door opener: the key to the building, which can be obtained by booking ahead. On the last floor, you will find a hybrid location, at once restaurant, bar where you can smoke hookah, and tea salon. The whole apartment is a contemporary art gallery, offering temporary exhibitions updated on a regular basis. Choose a comfortable bench seat under the glass atrium and enjoy the charming and singular atmosphere while gazing at the sumptuous view of the sky and the roofs of Saint Petersburg. The bohemian feel of the place is highlighted on the menu, dedicated to dishes from around the world. The owner's favourite recipes, which he discovered along his various travels, find a new interpretation using 100% natural ingredients. Do not miss the cep mushroom tagliatelle with cream, or the falafels and homemade pita bread. Vegans are not left out, as many alternate recipes are available. An ideal spot to warm up with a tea cup in a unique environment.

Kvartira Kosti Kreutz

kreutzflat.com/en

content.title: Dashkova Residence, the courtyard of tsars

introduction.small: Dive into Russian history at the Dashkova Residence hotel, nestled in an ancient building on Galernaya street.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dashkova Residence, the courtyard of tsars

paragraphs.text:
Here at the Dashkova Residence hotel on Galernaya, the city's oldest street running parallel to the Neva river, you will find the true soul of Saint Petersburg. It is as much part of the national history as the many palaces built under the Russian Empire that surround it. This 18th-century building is the former residence of princess Catherine Dachkov (Ekaterina Romanovna Dashkova in Russian). Confidante of Empress Catherine II, she was a key character of the Russian Enlightenment, having notably founded the Russian Imperial Academy in 1783, based on the French Academy and discussions with Voltaire and Diderot during a Paris trip.

This particular period atmosphere is felt in every room of the hotel, while keeping the Dutch-inspired design both modern and welcoming. However, as a historical building, note that the mansion has no elevator. Very popular with travellers looking for a romantic stay (even on a budget), the Dashkova Residence remembers journeying families. Some rooms can therefore welcome four persons, just like the studio – which offers an unobstructed view of the gardens. As a guest of honour of Princess Dashkov, halfway between the Hermitage and the Bronze Horseman statue, you are plunged into the very heart of Saint Petersburg's imperial past.

content.title: Kuznya, gastronomical fusion food in a foundry

introduction.small: On New Holland's artificial island off Saint Petersburg, Kuznya is a hybrid location, Russian restaurant with worldwide overtones by day and disco by night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Kuznya, gastronomical fusion food in a foundry

paragraphs.text:
In Russian, Kuznya means "foundry". And for good reason, the restaurant set up home amid one of the 19th-century red brick buildings of the New Holland island. The foundry was entirely renovated into a trendy space very popular with the Saint Petersburg youth. Kuznya House has retained this industrial thematic and reveals decoration from the same era as the building, with largely Pre-Revolutionary-inspired design. Stone walls, wooden floors, rugs and geometrical patterns on warm-coloured bench seats are somehow on the kitsch side. The menu offers Russian cuisine that blends with various inspirations from around the world, from coal-grilled chicken with harissa and yogurt to a goose stew served with wheat and a poached egg or roasted halibut with cauliflower mash and zucchini chips. Once you are done with dessert, the second part of the evening can start: multicoloured tables and ottomans will be removed to clear out the dancefloor. Let the party begin!

content.title: Style and originality at Wynwood Hotel

introduction.small: For one night, find solace in loft-style contemporary hotel in the heart of Saint Petersburg.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Style and originality at Wynwood Hotel

paragraphs.text:
The historical building in which Wynwood Hotel has set up home still exudes Imperial time traces. Its name draws inspiration from the Wynwood Art District in Miami, once ran down and now rehabilitated in a street art spirit, which the hotel design also reflects with its subtle use of bricks, iron, glass and wood. The very spacious and brightly lit 38 rooms offer unobstructed views over the House of Books – former headquarters of American company Singer, built in 1904 in an Art Nouveau style, and subsequently one of the largest bookshops in Europe – and the Kazan Cathedral. Hidden under a glass roof and sheltered by a little courtyard that is typical of Saint Petersburg, the aptly-named Jungle restaurant will offer you an unforgettable culinary experience amid its tropical garden. As for the Rooftop Bar, it welcomes you at any moment of the day. Order a fresh and handmade fruit juice, as well as delicious cocktails - to be enjoyed in moderation. A ceviche, platter of oysters or grilled meat will satisfy your appetite, unless you prefer to make the best of the hotel's central location to wander around the Northern Venice, replete with bistros, cafés and all kinds of restaurants.

content.title: Toast to the Russian Vodka Museum

introduction.small: Vodka lovers, discover the history and secrets of making this traditional Russian alcohol.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Toast to the Russian Vodka Museum

paragraphs.text:
Exclusively dedicated to vodka, this museum is the first of its kind in the world. It provides a thorough overview of the country's vodka-related culture and customs and different production methods, traditional consumption patterns and large producers of this famous beverage that has been an integral part of Russian life for centuries.
The highlight of the museum is its collection of bottles that belonged to the factories of the “distillation kings”, most dating back to the 19th century. In addition, you will have the opportunity to admire some splendid portraits of Tsars, as well as a magnificent set of dishes and antique china.
A tasting awaits you at the end of your tour. In a room decorated in the style of Russian bars of the early 20th century, you will be offered to taste three different types – with moderation, of course –, for example, the chilli-flavoured vodka, all accompanied by delicious local hors-d'oeuvre.

High fashion to the max. This is the main feature of W Hotels, which are design-savvy and ultra-chic. The US chain Starwood installed its first W Hotel in Saint Petersburg, near St. Isaac's Cathedral, in 2011. The Italian architects responsible for its decor were inspired by Fabergé eggs those precious jewelled pieces created in the late 19th century at the request of Tsar Alexander III.

The rooms are nice looking and very cosy, in beige and white punctuated with red or purple. They are also equipped with the latest technologies. In the bathrooms, the shower is like a warm rainfall, very welcome after long walks in the city. The breakfast is hearty. Grab a drink at the bar terrace on the 8th floor, one of the favourite watering holes among the city's young urban set.

content.title: Russian Museum: from icons to abstract painting

introduction.small: This museum houses an extraordinary collection of Russian art from the 12th to the 20th century, in a mix of tradition and modernity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Russian Museum: from icons to abstract painting

paragraphs.text:
Discover the full arc of Russian art at this museum, which not only has religious icons from the 12th to the 17th century, but also more recent works. It was built on the order of Tsar Alexander III, who had an impressive 19th century art collection. His son Nicolas II opened the museum in 1898 in the Mikhailovsky Palace.

The works are presented in chronological order. Don't miss the paintings of Peredvizhniki movement: also known in English as the Wanderers or the Itinerants, these fine arts students were at odds with the official style in the 19th century. The most famous painting, Barge Haulers on the Volga, by Ilya Repin, is a denunciation of forced labour. Among the many works on display, you'll discover artists little known in the West. You'll also see abstract paintings by Malevich and Kandinsky, and a few by Chagall.

Finally, part of the museum features folk handicrafts: toys, lacquered boxes, ceramics, and jewellery.

Russian Museum (Russkiy muzey)

content.title: Mansarda: fine cuisine overlooking St. Isaac's

introduction.small: Gilded and beautiful, the Mansarda restaurant is also famous for its cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mansarda: fine cuisine overlooking St. Isaac's

paragraphs.text:
The Quattro Corti business centre stands on Pochtamtskaya ulitsa, between the Neva river and the pier of the Moika river. Inside this glass building, take the elevator to the sixth floor. It's a strange place for a restaurant, yet this is where the Mansarda set up home, with a large glass room that offers breathtaking views over the roofs of the city and the golden dome of St. Isaac's Cathedral.

In summer, the beautiful terrace that surrounds the restaurant opens. With attentive service and a varied menu, the Mansarda attracts a young and hip local clientele. At blonde-wood tables, they dine on international, Asian-influenced cuisine: sushi mingle with seabass ceviche, beef borsch with a hot shrimp soup, and a truffle focaccia with some caviar. Incredibly talented, chef Dmitry Bogachev also provides an excellent wine list in perfect pairing with your dish. There is no better way to transcend your stay in Saint Petersburg.

content.title: Peterhof: the Russian Versailles of Peter the Great

introduction.small: With its magnificent gardens, canal, waterfalls, and palace, Peterhof symbolises the triumph of imperial power.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Peterhof: the Russian Versailles of Peter the Great

paragraphs.text:
Tsar Peter the Great admired Versailles so much he decided to build his own on the Baltic Sea. Completed in 1723, his palace, however, is more modest, but Peter's successors never ceased to expand on it.

Rightly so, because all is a wonder: living rooms, ballroom, ceremonial rooms, study everything is beautiful. Stroll around the area and admire the Grand Cascade, with its 142 fountains, the canal which opens onto the sea, the Marly Palace, the Cottage, the Hermitage. Not to mention the palace of Monplaisir, where Peter the Great liked to stay and receive guests.

The park holds many random surprises among its shaded walkways: flowerbeds, sculptures, and half-hidden fountains. From mid-April to mid-October, the Meteor hydrofoil connects Peterhof with Saint Petersburg in about 30 minutes; it departs from the pier opposite the Hermitage. Otherwise, the domain, which is about 25 km away from the city centre, is easily accessible by car, bus or commuter train.

content.title: Peter and Paul Fortress: the city's place of birth

introduction.small: Formerly a prison, this citadel is today a promenade. One can even swim on its beach.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Peter and Paul Fortress: the city's place of birth

paragraphs.text:
The construction of the Peter and Paul Fortress, at the mouth of the Neva, was inaugurated by Peter the Great. Begun in 1703 on swampy ground where hundreds of workers perished due to extreme weather, it protected the city during the war with Sweden. It was later transformed into a political prison.

Today, it consists of various buildings that you can visit, most especially the magnificent Peter and Paul Cathedral, which contains several tombs of the imperial Romanov family. Its spire, which rises to 122 metres, is one of the symbols of Saint Petersburg. You can also visit the Boathouse, a shelter specially built for Peter I's botik, a warship used as a fore figure of the Russian fleet. Do not miss the dark dungeons of the Trubetskoy Bastion, where enemies of the regime were locked up. Other sites in the eight-museum complex include the Monument to the Heroic Defenders of Leningrad, the Museum of Printing, the Saint Petersburg Museum of Avant-garde (Matyushin's House) and the Engineering House, which was used to shelter the tsar's own builders during the construction of the city.

The nearby beach is very busy during the summer. In winter, brave souls break the ice and take an invigorating dip…

Peter and Paul Fortress (Petropávlovskaya Krépost)

content.title: Probka: for authentic Italian cuisine

introduction.small: A very popular Italian restaurant with a modern and elegant clientele.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Probka: for authentic Italian cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Saint Petersburg can boast many great Russian fine dining establishments, but it also has some standout foreign cuisine. And some of these restaurants manage to live up to their reputation. This is the case for Probka, serving Italian cuisine. Originally, its owner, Aram Mnatsakanov, imported wines from Italy and France. Now he runs a group of restaurants in Saint Petersburg and Moscow, all highly popular among locals and tourists. As for Probka, it is located on the ground floor of an office building, a few steps away from the Leningrad zoo, the Peter and Paul Fortress and the Neva river. The menu boasts eclectic selections like the oven-baked eggplant hummus, tuna tartare, seafood fritters with aioli, taglioni in squid ink and salmon caviar, as well as various salads, pizzas and risottos, all accompanied by excellent wines by the glass or bottle. The list has more than a hundred wines from around the world, to be enjoyed in moderation. Admittedly, this restaurant is located a bit outside of downtown, but it is easily accessible by metro (Sportivnaya station).

content.title: Living with Pushkin, along the Moika River

introduction.small: A visit to the apartment where the great Russian writer died. His office remains unchanged.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Living with Pushkin, along the Moika River

paragraphs.text:
Even though he was born in Moscow in 1799, the most famous of all Russian writers, Alexander Pushkin, died in Saint Petersburg in 1837. He had moved a few months before his death to this beautiful Classic mansion on the banks of the Moika. This is where he lost his life, after a duel with an officer who had made advances to his wife Natalia.

He was only 38 years old, but had already written works which had become literary hallmarks, like the novel Eugene Onegin and the poem The Bronze Horseman, for example. They would change Russian literature forever. In 1925, the apartment was restored and opened to the public.

His study is exactly as he left it, with his personal belongings on the desk, and his rich library of hundreds of books in several languages. Every January 29th, the day of his death, admirers lay flowers at the door.

content.title: Tsarskoye Selo: the magnificence of the tsars

introduction.small: This imperial domain, with its magnificent palaces, is arguably the grandest in Saint Petersburg.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tsarskoye Selo: the magnificence of the tsars

paragraphs.text:
The memory of Pushkin hangs over 'the village of the Tsars'. He owned a dacha here. But Tsarskoye Selo, some 20 km from Saint Petersburg, is mostly a grandiose imperial domain. It owes its magnificence to Empress Catherine II.

You will be dazzled by the splendour of the place: the blue facade; the inlaid floors; the clocks, the gilt, and the frescoes and a cabinet whose walls are completely covered with panels of amber, patiently rebuilt after their destruction during the German occupation. Do not miss the grand ballroom with its painted ceiling and gilded carvings, the dining rooms, the enfilade suites of rooms, and the richly decorated chapel.

In the park, terraces, statues, and flowerbeds dot the French gardens. Nearby is the Alexander Palace, one of the favourite vacationing residences of Nicolas II and his family. They were placed under house arrest there in 1917, just before their tragic end.

content.title: Saint Petersburg: a city on the water

introduction.small: Islands and inlets… The city can also be discovered by its canals but only in summer.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint Petersburg: a city on the water

paragraphs.text:
Saint Petersburg is a city of water. By flowing into the sea, the Neva River forms a delta containing an area of countless islands and three inlets. The city centre is surrounded by three canals that are lined with beautiful homes. The Moika, the Griboyedov Canal, and the Fontanka are spanned by many bridges, a number of which are decorated with beautiful sculptures and lamps. The floods, once the nightmare of the inhabitants, have now been curbed.

To remember them, an obelisk near the Blue bridge marks the highest levels reached by the deadliest of the floodwaters. Choose a tour of one or several hours, in the city alone or all the way to the Gulf of Finland. When evening falls, the illuminated facades of the palaces along the Neva provide a magical spectacle. At night, the bridges are opened, to the admiration of tourists. The canals are navigable between May and mid-October. But a visit to the frozen Neva in winter is also unforgettable.

content.title: The Astoria, a true institution

introduction.small: This five-star hotel, more than a century old, offers impeccable service, comfort, and glamour

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Astoria, a true institution

paragraphs.text:
Inaugurated in 1912, the Astoria, overlooking St. Isaac's Cathedral, has a long history. Some of it was tragic: for example, when it was converted into a hospital for artists and writers during the Leningrad siege. Some of it, more amusing: when, for example, James Bond stayed here for some scenes of the 1995 film GoldenEye.

Today, it is in the heart of the historic district, a modern and very comfortable hotel with 83 tastefully furnished rooms and 86 suites. The decorator Olga Polizzi, the owner's sister, used colourful bedspreads and carpets to pump up the glamor. The bathrooms are in white marble. Breakfast is served in the winter garden, the same place where Hitler was planning to organise a banquet to celebrate his victory over the city. Obviously, and to the world's relief, it never happened.

Enjoy the buffet, prepared by a French chef, who also remains in charge for dinner.

content.title: The Yusupov Palace: the sumptuous residence of a princely family

introduction.small: It is here, in this beautiful setting, that Rasputin, the guru who had a destructive influence over the imperial family, was murdered.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Yusupov Palace: the sumptuous residence of a princely family

paragraphs.text:
Prince Felix Yusupov remains famous for having, in 1916, assassinated Rasputin, the mystic healer whose influence on the royal family, especially the Empress Alexandra, wife of Nicolas II, was as powerful as it was harmful.

Many regarded him as a debauched charlatan. The Yusupov family, richer than the tsar, it was said, had acquired in 1830 this yellow building with columns, built in 1760, to house their magnificent collection of art. Despite the years, the building has been beautifully preserved. Visit the ballroom, the Moorish lounge, the 180-seat rococo-style theatre, and the basement, which witnessed the last days of Rasputin. All give testimony to the splendour of this family. The paintings and art objects collected by the Yusupov are now mostly visible in the Hermitage. As for Prince Felix Yusupov, he was arrested and exiled to Paris, where he lived until his death in 1967.

content.title: White Nights Festival: when the sun never sleeps

introduction.small: In summer, days stretch out until night no longer exists, and parties go on till dawn.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: White Nights Festival: when the sun never sleeps

paragraphs.text:
On the 60th parallel north, the city of Saint Petersburg is below the Arctic Circle, but not by much. This location allows it to enjoy, around the June 21st summer solstice, very short nights.

A diffuse light remains around the clock as the sun barely slips below the horizon. After the long, cold, and snowy winter, and the short spring, the White Nights reawaken the population in every street of Saint Petersburg. Everything is a reason to go out and sit at cafes, stroll along the banks of the Neva River, or attend one of the many festivals or other artistic events that regularly take place. On the river, lift bridges open up to let ships back in again.

Every night, the city comes alive. This period, which lasts from late May to mid-July, is very popular with tourists who revel in this joyful atmosphere, so book your hotel and theatre tickets well in advance.

content.title: Teplo: a warm and very Russian atmosphere

introduction.small: Comfortable, friendly, and affordable, Teplo restaurant gets everyone's vote. You will feel right at home.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Teplo: a warm and very Russian atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
In Russian, the name of this restaurant means 'heat'. And it is true that the atmosphere is warm here, which appeals to the many customers who take refuge in its small rooms with many nooks and corners. The decor is original, if a bit eclectic, but very friendly, with a young and smiling staff. A small terrace on an outdoor courtyard add to Teplo's charm.

But the real draw is the food, simple, varied, and perfectly prepared by the chef. Russian recipes dominate, but there are international dishes, too, and good vegetarian ones as well. If desserts are your thing, then try the banana, strawberry and cream cake, a Napoleon covered in fresh blueberries or the delicious and homemade dry nut cake. There is a small playroom for children, which will give parents a breather and time to enjoy their meal. Located next to the Astoria Hotel, this restaurant offers good value and is therefore ideal for family dining.

content.title: The Mariinsky, for unforgettable shows

introduction.small: Formerly known as the Kirov, the Mariinsky Theatre's ballet and opera repertoire are among the best in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Mariinsky, for unforgettable shows

paragraphs.text:
Like the Bolshoi in Moscow, the Mariinsky in Saint Petersburg has a reputation for producing great performances. In Russia, dance is a tradition that dates back to the 18th century, when the first imperial ballet school was created. Legendary dancers like Rudolf Nureyev and Mikhail Baryshnikov trained in the city before choosing freedom in exile, in Europe and the United States.

During your stay, don't miss an evening ballet performance at the Mariinsky, among the most spectacular the world over – we recommend you check beforehand whether the company is on tour elsewhere, it happens! Built in 1860, the theatre is truly superb. Especially admirable are its columns, painted ceiling, stage curtain, and stunning lobby, with its beautiful pilasters and bas-reliefs. Opera is the other big draw; it was here that The Queen of Spades by Tchaikovsky was presented for the first time, in 1890.

content.title: The Hermitage: a fabulous art collection

introduction.small: On the Neva, the Hermitage is one of the most famous and most richly endowed museums in the world. This is not to be missed.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Hermitage: a fabulous art collection

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1764 by Catherine II, also known as Catherine the Great, who wanted a place to store her art collection, the Hermitage, opened to the public in 1852 under Tsar Nicolas I, now holds over three million works in several buildings.

The main building is the Winter Palace, the residence of the imperial family until the October Revolution. Built in Baroque style between 1754 and 1762, this three-storey mansion has a green and white façade, almost 2,000 windows, 1,786 doors and 1,500 richly decorated rooms. It is impossible to see all the collections, so make your choices based on your interests: goldsmithing, antiques, paintings, weapons, coins, or the archaeological wonders of the Urals and Siberia. All epochs are represented: there are many paintings by Rembrandt and Rubens, but also by Watteau, Fragonard, Renoir, Monet, and countless others.

Among the masterpieces, The Dance by Matisse, Montagne Sainte-Victoire seen from Bellevue by Cézanne, and Man with Arms Crossed by Picasso. More than ever, any trip to Saint Petersburg must include a visit to the Hermitage.

The Hermitage (Gosudarstvennyy Ermitazh)

content.title: Lion Palace St. Petersburg: rooms overlooking St. Isaac

Near St. Isaac's Cathedral, the former residence of Princess Lobanova-Rostovskaya – a gift from her generous husband – designed by the French architect Auguste de Montferrand and completed in 1819, has become a gorgeous hotel a few years ago.

This 'House with Lions', as it was long called because of the two marble lions that watch over its yellow facade, was renovated by luxury hotel group Four Seasons. The 183 rooms and 26 suites are furnished in a classical style, and each square inch offers something special for lovers of lavish comfort. Velvet drapes, silk, wood floors, chandeliers, marble, everything is sumptuous. A majestic staircase leads from the lobby to the bedrooms. The two stylish restaurants, one Asian, the other Italian, will make you swoon. To complete your cocooning, hit the Luceo Spa, which has eight treatment rooms, a gym, and a swimming pool. The Lion Palace St. Petersburg is most definitely a luxury jewel for discerning travellers from around the world.

content.title: Belmond Grand Hotel Europe: the luxury of the tsars

introduction.small: In the heart of the city, on Nevsky Prospect, this luxury hotel offers refined and comfortable rooms.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Belmond Grand Hotel Europe: the luxury of the tsars

paragraphs.text:
This hotel has reigned over the city since 1875, despite some interruptions due to conflicts. On Nevsky Prospect, its majestic pink facade is impressive, hearkening back to the days of the tsars, when the aristocracy held sumptuous balls. This was, after all, Tchaikovsky's favourite place to stay. From the lobby, this five-star hotel, the first in the country, is filled with columns, statues, and marble in short, all the splendour of eternal Russia.

The rooms 276 in total spread over five floors are very traditional, with floral curtains and mahogany furniture. The suites are of exquisite taste, with beautiful antique furniture. Breakfast is provided in the Europe, the sumptuous Art Nouveau dining restaurant, accompanied by a pianist. At dinner, the chef's specialities have made this one of the best restaurants in town – and the oldest in all Russia as well. On Friday nights, gala ceremonies take place, interspersed with ballet dancing and opera performances.

content.title: The Idiot, Russian cuisine in the style of Dostoevsky

introduction.small: Traditional Russian cuisine in a relaxed atmosphere that evokes the past. Let The Idiot seduce you…

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Idiot, Russian cuisine in the style of Dostoevsky

paragraphs.text:
Named after the book by Fyodor Dostoyevsky, the famous Russian author who wrote The Idiot (1874) and lived in this neighbourhood, this restaurant has a quaint atmosphere, yet delicious food. A few minutes away from Nevsky Prospect, the building is pretty common and easy to miss.

Once inside, you'll find a row of vaulted rooms lined with books, photos, and paintings, while leather sofas invite to relax. Card games, backgammon, and chess boards are available, laid out on the tables. But it is for the food itself that regulars come to The Idiot: Russian blinis with salmon and cucumber or fish eggs and whipping cream, herring with marinated onions and potatoes, borsch, Stroganoff beef with mushrooms… as well as good vegetarian fare.

A small glass of vodka is offered to all comers, on the house. At the bar, try one of the famous cocktail specials, especially the well-named 'Crime and Punishment', one of the many specialities paying tribute to the creator of The Brothers Karamazov.
